cool, you are welcome

@bennettaur Thanks for you work on this so far.

I want this change to be included in the next release which should go out very shortly, so I will merge what we have so far and finalize the patch.

This pull request can be closed now.

I've finished your changes and merged them into trunk. Those changes will be included in the next release. Thanks!

Merged into trunk, you can close this pull request now.

Thanks!

Looks good, merged into trunk.

Thanks!

@briancurtin Btw, I just noticed my account still doesn't have `HKG` endpoints in the service catalog?

What is the plan for rolling this endpoint to user's service catalogs?

For brand new customers it's available immediately, but access for existing customers will be rolled out over a couple of days starting October 28 (or email me and I can have you included earlier). I didn't know that part of it when I submitted this PR - just found that out this morning. In the future I'll include any rollout information in these types of PRs.

The pull request looks good, but it needs a test case which verifies that right query parameters are sent to the server (in this case, that is `KeyName`).

Also next time when making a changes like this, please link to a reference guide on the provide page (in this case, that would be http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/ApiReference-query-DeleteKeyPair.html).
Test for this function already in trunk, this "patch" fix set up a arguments correspondence to api docs

@gigimon Yes, but the existing test case (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/test/compute/test_ec2.py#L382), doesn't test that the right arguments are sent to the API which is the important part in this case.

You can see an example of how other tests do that here - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/test/compute/test_ec2.py#L709
please check, I added test for arguments
@gigimon Looks good. Please attach this patch to the JIRA issue and I'll merge it into trunk.
@Kami  complete, please see in JIRA

@gigimon Merged, this pr can be closed now.

Thanks.
Ok, Thx!

This pull request includes several fixes. 
1)list_locations wouldn't show the correct datacenters you are able to create a node
2)list_sizes has a few templates, since SoftLayer does not have sizes as a component, but rather accepts cpu/ram/disk info. The new templates added hopefully are realistic to a big percentage of what a user would choose. Also fixed in create_node to accept the data from sizes -contained a bug in cpu/ram
3)include some more helpful data on node.extra, in list_nodes
4) add ex_start_node and ex_stop node
5)Fix states for halted/paused and also newle created nodes.
Also fixed the tests to work with changes made on list_locations/list_sizes. Agree that more tests have to be added.

Can you please also add some examples of how to use this functionality to - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/docs/compute/drivers/ec2.rst

And yes, the file is currently empty. The reason for that is that we just recently started bootstrapping provider specific documentation.
Ok, I switched to Sphinx style docstrings, and added an example to the docs. How does it look now?

@oldpatricka Looks good.

Please squash all the commits into one and attach patch to the corresponding JIRA ticket and I'll merge it into trunk.
Great, the patch is attached to the ticket (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-417), so I'm closing this request. Thanks for the prompt responses!
Current version of libcloud appears to use 1.0 still. Have you made any more progress or created a ticket on Apache's JIRA?

@rgbkrk Yes, latest published version (0.13.2) still uses auth 1.0, but trunk includes those changes and uses auth 2.0.

Those changes (https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/upgrade_notes.html#libcloud-0-14-0) will also be included in the next release (0.14.0) which is currently being voted on (http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/libcloud-dev/201310.mbox/%3CCAJMHEmKfWmMgt0c0idmAbE6Fxg67cRTo-VbH4Y9djsk4J9X%3D%3Dg%40mail.gmail.com%3E).
Oh sweet. Thanks @Kami! I'll start watching the mailing list too. I'm looking forward to this.
@rgbkrk You are welcome. And yeah, libcloud-dev is fairly low volume.

Merged into trunk, thanks.

As noted on the IRC, please always base your pull request branch on top of latest trunk.

This can be achieved this way:
1. Make sure you are on trunk - `git checkout trunk`
2. Sync your fork trunk with upstream trunk - `git pull upstream trunk`
3. Base your new branch of latest trunk - `git checkout -b your_branch_name`
It would also be good to add some documentation which explains how to use this driver to `docs/compute/drivers/cloudframes.rst`.
We should consider running flake8 over the code, and making it part of CI to catch these issues

@alex I agree.

In the past we had pep8, pylint and pyflakes running on Apache buildbot, but a failure was never marked as fatal. The reason for that is that there were a lot of legacy issues which no-one cleaned up (there were some attempts, but no managed to get through).

I also tried to manually enforce pep8 for new patches, but obviously humans are bad at tasks like this and it should really be part of an automatic process.

To get it passing and hook it up as part of the CI process, we should do the following:
1. Clean up the existing code
2. Ignore line limit errors emitted by pep8 - mock function methods can get really long and there is no nice way to split them. Other, a little better solution would be to only allow longer lines in `test_*` files. Ideal solution would be to change the way mocking works, but that's too big of a task and out of scope for cleaning this up.
3. Add `# noqa` pragma where necessary to silence `imported but unused errors`

A similar discussion is happening in buildbot land and one of the developers there recently suggested this:

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/autopep8

Im about to take it for a spin on one of my pet projects.

On 25 Oct 2013, at 10:09, Tomaz Muraus notifications@github.com wrote:

> @alex I agree.
> 
> In the past we had pep8, pylint and pyflakes running on Apache buildbot, but a failure was never marked as fatal. The reason for that is that there were a lot of legacy issues which no-one cleaned up (there were some attempts, but no managed to get through).
> 
> I also tried to manually enforce pep8 for new patches, but obviously humans are bad at tasks like this and it should really be part of an automatic process.
> 
> To get it passing and hook it up as part of the CI process, we should do the following:
> 
> Clean up the existing code
> Ignore line limit errors emitted by pep8 - mock function methods can get really long and there is no nice way to split them. Other, a little better solution would be to only allow longer lines in test_\* files. Ideal solution would be to change the way mocking works, but that's too big of a task and out of scope for cleaning this up.
> Add # noqa pragma where necessary to silence imported but unused errors
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
@briancurtin change looks good, but the tests need to be fixed before it can be merged.

Besides the typo thing, it looks good now.

Please make sure pep8 passes on the new files, squash all the commits and attach a final patch to the corresponding JIRA ticket.
Updated to use an assertRaises format that works on all versions.
@briancurtin merged, thanks.
@briancurtin I just started working on cleaning up all flake8 issues around 1 hour ago. I'm almost done with a full cleanup.

Merged into trunk, this pull request can be closed now.

Thanks.

(just doing some pull request cleanup)

@talkasa - Sorry for the delay. Until recently, we (libcloud developers) weren't notified about new pull request so this one managed to slip through.

Can you please close this pull request and if those changes are still relevant, synchronize your fork with the latest trunk and generate a new one?

Thanks!

@tomaz
really it's wrong your libvirt Driver, if the node is stopped, his id are
-1 and then you can't start node by id, all the stopped nodes have IDs -1,
please get a look on Libvirt documentation

really the start node in libvirt driver are wrong, please read the libvirt documentation, the halted node have -1 as ID, you cannot look up node by id with id = -1, the good way is to look up nobe by name or by uuid

@fly Thanks, I didn't know you were working on a pull request. I thought you just submitted a bug / feature request so I've beat you to it - https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=libcloud.git;a=commitdiff;h=9174d71

@fitati Please make sure you synchronize your branch with the latest trunk (https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/development.html#syncing-your-git-hub-repository-with-an-official-upstream-git-repository) since it appears to be out of date.
thanks @Kami, closing.
Sure thing!
Closing as it was merged just over 2 years ago.

This is slightly off topic, but one thing I would also eventually like to do is refactor the `libcloud.utils.pubkey` module.

I would add a new `PublicKey` class which would handle all the public key related methods which are currently exported by `pubkey` module

Advantages of this approach are:
- No need to copy and paste "if pycrypto available" stuff
- This class would know how to deal with different key types (rsa, ecdsa, dsa)

Anyway, that's more of a low priority refactoring.

@fly Thanks, besides the lint issues (https://travis-ci.org/apache/libcloud/jobs/13222251), it looks good.

Please address those, squash the commits, attach patch to the jira ticket and I'll merge it into trunk.
done. Thanks @Kami

Merged into trunk, this PR can be closed now.

Thanks!
Not sure why this wasn't automatically closed as a result of the commit, or why you can't close it yourself as a result of knowing that it's been committed... but sure - I can close it.
Can you please provide some reference which describes auth endpoints for ktucloud?

Also, those changes are unnecessary.

You can simply set `auth_url` to `https://ssproxy.ucloudbiz.olleh.com/auth/` and it will work as expected - If you set `auth_url` to `https://ssproxy.ucloudbiz.olleh.com/auth/` and `_auth_version` to `1.0`, final request URL will look exactly like you want it to - `https://ssproxy.ucloudbiz.olleh.com/auth/v1.0`

That's also the way Rackspace and other drivers handle that.

@Kami 
and KT UCloud support 2 auth page.
1. http://https://ssproxy.ucloudbiz.olleh.com/auth/v1.0
2. https://api.ucloudbiz.olleh.com/storage/v1/auth

I intent to give an functionality to change auth uri, even it is not ended with "v1.0" or "v1.1/auth" or "v2.0/tokens"

@Kami and I found something wrong in openstack.py

I tried to follow your advice.
but in openstack.py

it just request "/v1.0" or something not combination of end part of url + auth_version.

if we want it to work well. we can change it to like this.

'''python
(host, port, secure, request_path) = \
            self._tuple_from_url(self.auth_url)

uri = "%sv%s"%(request_path, self.auth_version)
'''

but I think it is also weird.

because when version 2.0 or 1.1 it should add "/v1.1/auth" in authenticate function in openstack.py

so. I think setting auth url explicitly is better than now.

what do you think about this?

@charsyam Actually, you are right. There seems to be a bug / some nasty stuff going on in OpenStackAuthConnection class.

`OpenStackAuthConnection` class overrides `morph_action_hook` method (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/common/openstack.py#L122) which otherwise appends action to the request path (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/common/base.py#L638).

@mgogoulos bump, let us know if you need any help with addressing those comments.

Would be great to see this PR merged.

@Kami I pulled request again with your review.

and I will close this issue :) Thank you.

@charsyam Thanks for working on this!

Besides the comments I already posted, it also needs some test cases which test at least the following `auth_url` values:
1. `http://192.168.0.100/` - assume path (`/`) is already provided, nothing should be appended to the final url
2. `http://192.168.0.100/foo/bar` - assume path (`/foo/bar`) is already provided, nothing should be appended to the final url
3. `http://192.168.0.100/foo/bar/` - assume path (`/foo/bar/`) is already provided, nothing should be appended to the final url
4. `http://192.168.0.100` - assume path is not provided, depending on the`auth_version`, correct path should be appended to the final url
Build is failing (https://travis-ci.org/apache/libcloud/builds/13388540) - can you please fix the lint issues?

@Kami I have a question about this rule.
I might think many developers don't think about the last "/" of url.
so, they might expect "http://192.168.0.100/" and "http://192.168.0.100" is same.

so how about this. only 1 is changed.
1. http://192.168.0.100/ - assume path is not provided, depending on the auth_version, correct path should be appended to the final url
   1. http://192.168.0.100/foo/bar - assume path (/foo/bar) is already provided, nothing should be appended to the final url
   2. http://192.168.0.100/foo/bar/ - assume path (/foo/bar/) is already provided, nothing should be appended to the final url
   3. http://192.168.0.100 - assume path is not provided, depending on the auth_version, correct path should be appended to the final url
@Kami Fixed lint issue.  The build is green now, but let me know if you see any other issues.

@charsyam The problem with your approach is that there is no way to specify a URL where you don't any path to be appended (e.g. you want a final URL to be `http://192.168.0.100`).

Imo the confusion between no slash and `/` shouldn't be too big of a deal, as long as we document it well. This means updating this page (https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/docs/compute/drivers/openstack.rst) and updating method docstrings.

@wrigri Merged, this PR cam be closed now.

Thanks!
@Kami ok. it makes sense. I will change patch soon :)
@Kami I uploaded new patch. please review my test code(test_auth_url)
